badges.name: Application-specific chain
badges.description: This project is built to operate a specific application

badges.name: Ethereum with calldata
badges.description: This project is posting its data to Ethereum as calldata

display.name: Loopring
display.description: Loopring is a ZK Rollup exchange protocol for trading and payments.

liveness.explanation: Loopring is a ZK rollup that posts state diffs to the L1. For a transaction to be considered final, the state diffs have to be submitted and validity proof should be generated, submitted, and verified.

query.functionSignature: function submitBlocksWithCallbacks(bool isDataCompressed, bytes calldata data, ((uint16,(uint16,uint16,uint16,bytes)[])[], address[])  calldata config)

layer.description: The data is posted to Ethereum as calldata.

bridge.description: The validating bridge has access to all the data, as it is posted onchain.

stateValidation.description: SNARKs are succinct zero knowledge proofs that ensure state correctness, but require trusted setup.

dataAvailability.description: All of the data needed for proof construction is published on Ethereum L1.

exitWindow.description: There is no window for users to exit in case of an unwanted regular upgrade since contracts are instantly upgradable.

sequencerFailure.description: Users can force the sequencer to include a withdrawal transaction by submitting a request through L1 with a 0.02 ETH fee. If the sequencer is down for more than 15d, users can use the exit hatch to withdraw their funds. The sequencer can censor individual deposits, but in such case after 15d users can get their funds back.

proposerFailure.description: Users are able to trustlessly exit by submitting a Merkle proof of funds.

requirements: Upgrades executed by actors with more centralized control than a Security Council provide less than 7d for users to exit if the permissioned operator is down or censoring.
missing.principle: Compromising ≥75% of the Security Council should be the only way (other than bugs) for a rollup to indefinitely block an L2→L1 message (e.g. a withdrawal) or push an invalid L2→L1 message (e.g. an invalid withdrawal).

requirements.description: A complete and functional proof system is deployed.
The project calls itself a rollup.
State roots are posted to Ethereum L1.
Inputs for the state transition function are posted to Ethereum L1.

A source-available node exists that can recreate the state from Ethereum L1 data. Please note that the L2BEAT team has not verified the validity of the node source code. [View code](https://github.com/Loopring/loopring-subgraph-v2)
Users are able to exit without the help of the permissioned operators.
Upgrades executed by actors with more centralized control than a Security Council provide less than 7d for users to exit if the permissioned operator is down or censoring.

principle.description: Compromising ≥75% of the Security Council should be the only way (other than bugs) for a rollup to indefinitely block an L2→L1 message (e.g. a withdrawal) or push an invalid L2→L1 message (e.g. an invalid withdrawal).

requirements.description: Upgrades unrelated to onchain provable bugs provide less than 30d to exit.

additionalConsiderations.short: Loopring provides an orderbook decentralized exchange for spot trading. Arbitrary contracts are not supported.
additionalConsiderations.long: Loopring provides an orderbook decentralized exchange for spot trading. Arbitrary contracts are not supported.

dataAvailability.name: All data required for proofs is published onchain
dataAvailability.description: All the data that is used to construct the system state is published onchain in the form of cheap calldata. This ensures that it will always be available when needed.

operator.name: The system has a centralized operator
operator.description: The operator is the only entity that can propose blocks. A live and trustworthy operator is vital to the health of the system.

risks.text: the operator exploits their centralized position and frontruns user transactions.

references.title: ExchangeV3.sol#L315-L322 - Etherscan source code, submitBlocks function
LoopringIOExchangeOwner.sol#L123-L126 - Etherscan source code, hasAccessTo function call

forceTransactions.name: Users can force exit the system
forceTransactions.description: Force exit allows the users to escape censorship by withdrawing their funds. The system allows users to force the withdrawal of funds by submitting a request directly to the contract onchain.  The request must be served within a defined time period. If this does not happen, the system will halt regular operation and permit trustless withdrawal of funds.

risks.text: the operator refuses to include their transactions. However, there exists a mechanism to independently exit the system.

references.title: Forced Request Handling - Loopring design doc

exitMechanisms.name: Regular exit
exitMechanisms.description: The user initiates the withdrawal by submitting a regular transaction on this chain. When the block containing that transaction is settled the funds become available for withdrawal on L1.ZK proofs are required to settle blocks. Finally the user submits an L1 transaction to claim the funds.

exitMechanisms.name: Forced exit
exitMechanisms.description: If the user experiences censorship from the operator with regular exit they can submit their withdrawal requests directly on L1. The system is then obliged to service this request. Once the force operation is submitted and if the request is serviced, the operation follows the flow of a regular exit.

references.title: Forced Request Handling - Loopring design doc
ExchangeV3.sol#L8118 - Loopring source code, forceWithdraw function

exitMechanisms.name: Emergency exit
exitMechanisms.description: If the 15d deadline passes and the forced exit is still ignored the user can put the system into Withdrawal Mode, disallowing further state updates. In that case everybody can withdraw by submitting a merkle proof of their funds with their L1 transaction.

references.title: Forced Request Handling - Loopring design doc
ExchangeV3.sol#L8159 - Loopring source code, withdrawFromMerkleTree function

actors.name: LoopringMultisig
actors.description:
A Multisig with 2/3 threshold. 
This address is the owner of the following contracts: LoopringIOExchangeOwner, ExchangeV3 (proxy), BlockVerifier, AgentRegistry, LoopringV3. This allows it to grant access to submitting blocks, arbitrarily change the forced withdrawal fee, change the Verifier address and upgrade ExchangeV3 implementation potentially gaining access to all funds in DefaultDepositContract.

actors.name: Block Submitters
actors.description: Actors who can submit new blocks, updating the L2 state on L1.

actors.name: RollupOwner
actors.description: The rollup owner can submit blocks, set rollup parameters and shutdown the exchange.

ethereum.name: LoopringIOExchangeOwner
ethereum.description: Contract used by the Prover to submit exchange blocks with zkSNARK proofs that are later processed and verified by the BlockVerifier contract. It allows to give or revoke permissions to submit blocks and to open block submission to everyone.

ethereum.name: DefaultDepositContract
ethereum.description: ERC 20 token basic deposit contract. Handles user deposits and withdrawals.

ethereum.name: LoopringV3
ethereum.description: Contract managing LRC staking for exchanges (one Loopring contract can manage many exchanges). It also allows to change the forced withdrawal fee and the Verifier address.

ethereum.name: FastWithdrawalAgent
ethereum.description: Auxiliary contract allowing users to process fast withdrawals.

ethereum.name: ForcedWithdrawalAgent
ethereum.description: Auxiliary contract able to force withdrawals from L1 on behalf of users.

ethereum.name: BlockVerifier
ethereum.description: zkSNARK Verifier based on ethsnarks library.
ethereum.upgradeConsiderations: The Verifier contract address can be changed by the ProxyOwner.

ethereum.name: AgentRegistry
ethereum.description: Agent registry that is used by all other Loopring contracts. Currently used are FastWithdrawalAgent, ForcedWithdrawalAgent, DestroyableWalletAgent and a number of LoopringAmmPool contracts.

risks.text: a contract receives a malicious code upgrade. There is no delay on code upgrades.

stateValidation.description: Each update to the system state must be accompanied by a ZK proof that ensures that the new state was derived by correctly applying a series of valid user transactions to the previous state. These proofs are then verified on Ethereum by a smart contract.

categories.title: ZK Circuits
categories.description: Loopring utilizes Groth16 for their proving system. The source code of the circuits can be found [here](https://github.com/Loopring/protocol3-circuits).

risks.text: the proof system is implemented incorrectly.

categories.title: Verification Keys Generation
categories.description: Groth16 requires a circuit specific trusted setup, so they run their own ceremony. The first phase is run using Powers of Tau ceremony. Some of the instructions on how to regenerate the verification keys can be found [here](https://github.com/Loopring/trusted_setup/tree/loopring-3.6.2).

categories.title: Validity proofs
categories.description: Each update to the system state must be accompanied by a ZK proof that ensures that the new state was derived by correctly applying a series of valid user transactions to the previous state. These proofs are then verified on Ethereum by a smart contract.

proofVerification.shortDescription: Loopring is a DEX rollup on Ethereum.

verifiers.name: LoopringVerifier
verifiers.description: Loopring utilizes Groth16 for their proving system.

milestones.title: DeFi Closure Announcement
milestones.description: Loopring sunsets DeFi features to focus on the L2.

milestones.title: Loopring ZK Rollup is live
milestones.description: Loopring Protocol 3.0 is fully operational with support for orderbook trading on WeDex.

milestones.title: Loopring Protocol 3.6 Pre-release
milestones.description: Enhancements in transfers, order-book trading and AMM swap.

milestones.title: Loopring’s ZK Rollup AMM is Live
milestones.description: Improved implementation, enabling gas-free instant swaps and liquidity changes.

milestones.title: Loopring Supports Payments
milestones.description: Support for ERC20 transfers is live on Loopring.

milestones.title: DeFi Port is Live on Loopring
milestones.description: Dutch auctions, lending, and other DeFi functions can be performed on Loopring.

milestones.title: Loopring Supports NFTs
milestones.description: Loopring supports NFT minting, trading, and transfers.

milestones.title: Loopring DEX is online
milestones.description: ZK Rollup trading is live, as Loopring launches their order book based exchange.
